title: uk-gdp-shrank-20-first-full-month-covid-19-lockdown-statistics-show
story: With shops and factories closing and workers being sent home due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Office for National Statistics has revealed that economic activity was down by .% in April.It is the largest drop in a single month since records began in .The fall massively outstrips the then-record .% drop in March gross domestic productthat the ONS reported last month.Source: ONSIt means that GDP fell by .% in the three months to April and sets the UK on course for one of its worst quarters in history.Experts had been expecting Aprilrsquos GDP to contract by .%, according to a consensus compiled by Pantheon Macroeconomics.Commenting on todayrsquos GDP figures for April, deputy nationalstatistician for economic statistics Jonathan Athow said: ldquoAprilrsquos fall in GDP is the biggest the UK has ever seen, more than three times larger than last month and almost ten times larger than the steepest pre-COVID- fall. In April the economy was around % smaller than in February.ldquoVirtually all areas of the economy were hit, with pubs, education, health and car sales all giving the biggest contributions to this historic fall.ldquoManufacturing and construction also saw signicant falls, with manufacture of cars and housebuilding particularly badly affected.ldquoThe UKrsquos trade with the rest of the world was also badly affected by the pandemic, with large falls in both the import and export of cars, fuels, works of art and clothing.SNP Shadow Chancellor Alison Thewliss MP said: ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic has had a devastating impact on the economy, businesses and peoplersquos jobs and livelihoods. While the support brought forward by the Treasury so far has been welcome, there is so much more that needs to be donewe are to work towards a strong economic recovery.ldquoThe ONS statistics reveal a record slump of .% in GDP in April due to lockdown measures and the health crisis - worse than during the financial crash. This must serve as a wake-up call for the UK government to immediately extend and strengthen support schemes, not wind them down.ldquoBusinesses are struggling to survive, thousands of jobs are on the line, and households are taking a severe hit as people see a drop in income or job losses through no fault of their own.ldquoThe UK government should be alleviating that financial burden, rather than adding to it at this critical stage.ldquoWith the OECD also highlighting this week that the UK will suffer the worst economic impact of any of the developed countries, itrsquos clear that without immediate Treasury intervention to deliver financial relief and tailored support, our erse sectors and industries - such as manufacturing and agri - face a battle to survive.ldquoThe SNP will continue to pressure the UK government over its coronavirus economic plan - including calling for an extension for as long as is necessary to its Job Retention Scheme and support for the self-employed for the devolved nations.

title: sky-limit-building-new-world
story: As the coronavirus spread across the globe, and Italy then Spain went into lockdown it became clear to many that the UK might have to follow suit.A few companies saw the signs early and began to make plans for people to work from home with some, like global technology giant CGI, so far ahead of the game that one third of their workforce were already working remotely several weeks before the UK went into lockdown in March.Other industries were not as well prepared, either because of the nature of their work or because they didnrsquot have the means or knowledge to employ remote working.It is now clear that many sectors will be very heavily impacted and unemployment is already spiralling. School pupils, too, have been subject to major disruption and face an uncertain future as jobs and employment prospects disappear.Some workers and pupils, especially those without access to digital technology and skills, will be particularly hard hit and this is why CGI is keen to reach the most vulnerable to help them stay afloat in a post-Covid world.Through their community engagement programme, the company already has a focus on disadvantaged groups and this will continue and be strengthened further over the next year, according to CGIrsquos Director of Corporate Responsibility,Philippa Green.The company has almost , UK staffand she said they were keen to become involved and do what they could to help society recover.Before the pandemic hit, part of CGIrsquos community programme which focuses on supporting the next generation, was working in schools to interest pupils in careers in science, technology, engineering and maths.This work involved hosting STEM camps which engaged students across the UK in fun STEM related activities. The physical camps were cancelled when schools shut their doors but the organisation quickly pivoted and put a version online to help children, parents and schools through the lockdown.ldquoWe started doing it as an immediate response to the situation, said Green.ldquoLike many other people we thought it was going to be a short term project and children would be going back to school fairly quickly but it is now apparent that it is going to be longer than first expected so we are trying to pivot to the next stage.The content will remain online but unfortunately may not be of much use to pupils without a good digital connection or devices at home.Educationalists have already raised fears that this group of already disadvantaged children will suffer most because of the lockdown and CGI is keen to see how it can help reach them.ldquoMany children will not have been in school for six months which is a very long time. For youngsters thatrsquos a letime! said Green.CGI supports many organisations working with vulnerable and disadvantaged children and is working with them to reach those who do not have access to technology.The physical camps had often been targeted at the most vulnerable children in society and one of the companyrsquos last events in Glasgow was in a special educational needs school.One of the other aspects of the companyrsquos community programme is mentoring, when members go into an event in school to give older children career advice and an idea of what working le is like.ldquoTheir parents and their grandparents may not have worked and so the children may not have any idea about working le, said Green. ldquoEvents have been successful but we would normally do that in a school setting in a hall where our members can have one to one chats with pupils and that is obviously tricky to do at the moment.The company has started to record career mentoring videos to support some community groups.In the meantime there are still some new STEM from Home themes to come online before July and these will be released weekly until the end of June.Another group at the front of minds at CGI are those currently working through CGIrsquos graduate apprenticeships at Glasgow Caledonian and Edinburgh Napier Universities. ldquoWe are clear that these iniduals are key to the future of our business says Green.ldquoMark East and Maria Whittingham in our student recruitment team are working hard to ensure they have practical support whilst also thinking about the solutions for future student recruitment at this very important stage in their careers.Elsewhere, CGI, which supports The Glasgow Timesrsquo Streets Ahead initiative, continues to encourage its members to fundraise, with efforts being moved online. Members are asked to nominate regional charities for the companyrsquos charities fund whilst in recent weeks they have been at work fundraising for a foodbank to help those people hardest hit.Members also still have the opportunity to nominate local community sports teams for kit sponsorship.It is hoped this will come into its own as group physical exercise is increasingly encouraged and people get the chance to re-establish important bonds.RETRAINING WILL ENSURE NO-ONE IF LEFT BEHINDCGI has been in a better position than many companies to weather the pandemic lockdown and, as a result, is keen to help society recover post-Covid.ldquoIn February the world changed but some communities and industries are more impacted than others so it feels a bit remiss not to refocus our efforts for these areas in particular, said the companyrsquos Vice President Lindsay McGranaghan for Scotland.An important part of CGIrsquos work is its community programme and the company is now looking at how it can help communities and schools post-Covid.ldquoWe do a number of things around community benefit but we may have to rethink what we have been doing historically and tailor some of that to meet the impact of Covid, said McGranaghan.ldquoWe need to think about who is going to be most hard hit by the pandemic from an education perspective and whether we tailor our work to be more focused on the vulnerable children, as well as the industries impacted such as those where there have been quite heavy redundancies.Technology and technological skills have proved to be an immense boon during the pandemic lockdown and it is quickly becoming apparent that those who do not have access to technology, or know how to use it properly, are at a distinct disadvantage in the st century.McGranaghan feels that as a technology company, CGI is well placed to help both children and workers without these skills and could help retrain those in danger of being left behind.The company has already been working with the Wise Group in Glasgow to help retrain long term unemployed people in IT skills and is now wonderingthis could be extended to impacted industries and newly unemployed people.ldquoWe are looking at things like retraining opportunities, she said.ldquoWe have been reasonably resilient in the technology industry during Covid just because of the nature of the work we do and the question is whether we could put out a hand to dferent industries during what is going to be a dficult time ldquoWe want to look at how we can do this through our community programme.ldquoI think there is something there not only in terms of supporting the local authorities that we already work with, but also how we help with the recovery process.ldquoGiving back to the local community is very importantto us.

title: herald-diary-hippos-lawyers-best-avoided
story: GRUMPY chef and professional shoutyman Gordon Ramsay is bringing his TV show Hellrsquos Kitchen back to the UK. For the last  years itrsquos been broadcast in the States, where the Renfrewshire-born rage merchant has been forging a career. The Diary has never tasted Gordorsquos grub, though we enjoy his ability to instigate disharmony. After all, disharmony is also one of our selling points. Our readers often provide us with tales involving daft and disputatious behaviour, as the following classic tales underline. For instance, a frustrated correspondent once enquired: ldquoWhy canrsquot we shuffle the letters in anagram to make any other words Buffet buffer zoneANOTHER tale involving tension and food. Sheikh Hasina, Prime Minister of Bangladesh, was due in Dundee to officially open the second phase of the cityrsquos Verdant jute museum. Organisers of the state visit were surprised when a Bangladeshi security official asked what arrangements had been made for a food-taster to be on hand. One seasoned observer of Dundee civic beanfeasts remarked: ldquoThey neednrsquot worry. Therersquos bound to be a few councillors into the buffet before her.Plucky lawyersAN apocryphal story, we hope, from Lanarkshire, where two neighbours fell out in a dispute over a boundary wall. Eventually one of them goes to his lawyer. This prompts the neighbour to do likewise, but he inadvertently chooses the same lawyer. The solicitor patiently explains that he cannot act for both, but gives him a letter of recommendation to another lawyer. Although the letter is sealed, the neighbour opens it out of curiosity and reads an account of the dispute with the added paragraph: ldquoThese two are turkeys. You pluck one, and Irsquoll pluck the other.CarpetbaggerTHE scene is the carpet department of a high quality store in Edinburgh. A salesperson, verging on the hoity-toity, asks madam she likes this or that carpet.Finally, one to the customerrsquos liking is revealed. The housewe says: ldquoI can see that in my lounge, and bends down to touch the carpet.As she does so, she involuntarily passes wind. Embarrassed, she apologises.The salesperson replies: ldquoDonrsquot worry, madam, when you hear the price yoursquoll soil yourself.Married aliveWE received the following cynical suggestion for men about to get married. ldquoSave yourself some time and aggravation. Find a woman you donrsquot like and buy her a house.Lean timesA CHAPrsquoS strict diet had been successful, and he lost many stones. But the transformation was not achieved without facial evidence of a certain amount of strain. Or as a pal put it: ldquoIrsquove seen healthier faces keekinrsquo oot a coffin.Phone-y factTHERE was once stuck to a window of a telephone box in Plockton a BT sign with an illustration of a telephone and the words: ldquoYou may telephone from here.Wonders of wildleWE end with information that may be helpful to budding David Attenborough types. ldquoWhatrsquos the dference between a hippo and a zippo  a reader asked. ldquoA hippo is heavy. A zippo is a little lighter.

title: herald-view-timid-emerging-lockdown-may-damaging-delay-entering
story: Though the dreadful human cost in lives, health and well-being has naturally been the priority thus far, these figures are the starkest demonstration of the financial devastation. There is a real danger that,the process of reopening areas of the economy is botched, the long-term impact of the restrictions could prove as damaging as the disease itself.It is welcome, then, that the Scottish Government should have announced its provisional intent to lt restrictions on aspects of the tourist industry from July , as long as progress has been made to phase three of the route map for exit. It is not only a crucial part of our economy, but tourism and other industries which augment or are a component of it, including the transport, hospitality, sport and cultural sectors, are those that have suffered the harshest effects during the period of containment.It is cheering, too, that a move to phase two begins next week and, of course, that the death toll and rates of infection outside hospitals and care homes have fallen signicantly.There remain, however, major doubts about the handling and timetable of both the UK and Scottish Governments in moving towards lockdown in the pandemicrsquos early stages the grim toll in Scottish care homes, which has been characterised as the greatest disaster of the devolution era, must be counted as an abject failure of government. The likelihood that the UK may be already one of the worst,not the worst, affected countries in both fatalities and economic impact, ought to be a warning of the terrible dangers of mishandling the moves towards recovery.The considerable problems not yet resolved in testing are further grounds for caution. Yet an overzealous interpretation of the precautionary principle, or delay for the sake of token dference, may end up causing irreparable damage to peoplersquos jobs, livelihoods and personal lives.No one expects that things willto anything like normality soon. Firms and employers have already made huge changes to the way they expect to work, but there are numerous areas where government needs to balance risk and pragmatic action. Many employees will find it dficult toto work until schooling resumes. Social distancing requirements for workplaces will have a major impact on manufacturing productivity. The proposed UK quarantine rules obviously curtail foreign visitor numbers, and evenmany Britons choose to holiday at home, there will be transport dficulties for coaches, trains and ferries.Above all, without a serious examination of the guidance on the two-metre limit on public distancing, itrsquos dficult to see how many pubs, restaurants and small retail outlets can be commercially viable. Of course, it should be maintainedthe scientic evidence is clear but other countries have given more relaxed guidance without it leading to renewed outbreaks. It requires careful consideration, but being too timid in emerging from lockdown may be as damaging as the delay in entering it.

title: coronavirus-edinburgh-family-one-first-bring-covid-scotland
story: It comes after new genetic research revealed that the disease began circulating in Scotland during February and that it was brought here from continental Europe.Trish Lumsden, , tried to get her eight-year-old son, Christian, tested for the disease when he fell ill with a cough and fever on February , but was told by her GP that it was "probably a cold".By that time he had been back at school for nearly two weeks.UK-wide travel guidance on Italy was updated on February , by which time the country - which quickly became Europes Covid hotbed - had recorded hundreds of cases, a handful of deaths, and had quarantined  towns in Lombardy and Veneto.: Coronavirus spreading in Scotland in FebruaryAnyone who had arrived in the UK from northern Italy since February  was urged to self-isolatethey developed symptoms within  days, or to self-isolate as a precaution - regardless of symptoms -they had been in any of the areas by then under lockdown.Like hundreds of other Scottish holidaymakers who had travelled to Europe for the half-term break, the Lumsden family - who had been ski-ing in the Dolomites - ed to Scotland on February , making them exempt from this advice.But it is now thought the virus would have been widespread well before this date in Italyrsquos popular ski resorts and tourist centres such as Venice ndash which the Lumsdens visited hours before flying home."We didnt even realise until we go there that the Carnival was on and it was incredibly busy," said Mrs Lumsden."We couldnt even get into St Marks Square it was so busy. We didnt really think that much about it, but I do remember someone on the taxiboats - where youre really squashed in - coughing behind me."And I did think urgh, but I didnt think about it in relation to coronavirus."By the time Christian started getting a cough and a fever on the th they had opened the drive-thru test centre at the Western and because I was taking my eldest daughter to hockey on the Saturday and Christian was going to be going to his friends, I thought I could really be doing with getting him tested to make sure hes not going to infect other people."So I phoned the GP on Saturday morning and he said would you be worried about him normally,it wasnt for coronavirus . I said no, so he said  itll just be a cold then, dont worry about it - theyre only interestedyou came back from Italy since the th."He said since wed come back on the th there was nothing to worry about. At the time I thought that sounded a bit stupid, but now I think it sounds really stupid.": Number of patients in hospital cut % at start of outbreak"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","description": "Coronavirus in numbers: UK death toll at ,","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media gHqFBAP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests gHqFBAP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Mrs Lumsden, from Currie in Edinburgh,ed to work in the Royal Mile but both she and husband Tom soon developed "strange symptoms", including a hangover-like headache that lasted a week, fever, shivers, aching bones, and extreme fatigue that lasted for three weeks."The pair us of would be on the sofa and out for the count at pm," she said.Another of their four children, -year-old Stella, went on to develop a cough, and son Sebastian, , suffered a cough, fever and sore legs.All of the children were kept out of school after falling ill, but research now suggests that most people become infectious around three days before symptoms emerge.On January , Scotlands then chief medical officer Dr Catherine Calderwood said it was "highly likely" the countrys first Covid- case would be detected within days.In the end, the first known case was not identied until March  - in a patient in Tayside who had just ed from a ski trip to northern Italy.It is unclear exactly why the February  threshold was chosen, as Italy confirmed its first cluster of cases in Lombardy on the st and its first Covid deaths on the nd, suggesting - on the basis of the average incubation time and how long it usually takes to become seriously unwell - that the the virus had been circulating in the region for weeks.: Covids silent spreaders are the big question of the pandemicThe UK only escalated travel restrictions to ban "all but essential travel" to Italy on March , the day that Italy was plunged into a nationwide lockdown."The week after we came back was when it all kicked off, and everyone we knew was like oh, you were in Italy - you could be carrying it," said Mrs Lumsden."We could have been a spreader, I dont know."I would have loved to have had [Christian] tested and I cant really understand why he wasnt."At the time I did think it was strange, but you put your faith in the doctor and think they must know. But I really did question it."How many other people ing to Scotland from north Italy at this time called the NHS as they had symptoms and were told they were fine "Scientists have traced Scotlands Covid outbreak - which has now claimed  lives - to  unique versions of the virus imported from continental Europe.They are unsure exactly when it first arrived, but using genomic sequencing have been able to establish that community transmission was already underway in February - meaning that people with no history of travel to known Covid hotspots in Europe and Asia were becoming infected.However, interim CMO Dr Gregor Smith - who unveiled the findings last week - stressed that flu and other viral pathogens were also spreading in February.He said: "We wont be able to say with certaintysomeone who was experiencing the kinds of symptoms we would associate with Covid- - the cough, the fever - was specically associated with Covid-."A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoThe approach taken to advising ing travellers from specic countries and areas in mid-February was agreed by the four UK Chief Medical Officerson the best and most up to date expert scientic and medical advice at the time of making the decision.

title: scotland-gets-set-welcome-tourists
story: The Scottish Government has given the tourism and hospitality sectors a provisional reopening date of July , assuming the fight to suppress Covid- continues to be successful.But amid warnings ldquoMany tourism businesses on the islands which have seen no revenue since October  are on a knersquos edge and will be unable to survive until April  without some trading season this year, or further Government support, which has not yet been proposed.:Scotland set to enter lockdown Phase  NEXT WEEK - what changes for youldquoWersquod welcome a boost or a bounce, as opposed to a surge or an invasion, in autumn, when people who have been unable to come earlier in the year decide to visit in October or November which would really help our businesses, when social distance happens naturally, and you do have the space to feed your soul. Wersquoll need a bit of patience and understanding as we get back into gear and adjust to social distancing, restock some supplies, and deal with everyonersquos nervousness as we adapt to the new normal.ldquoWe are lucky that many of our visitors are regulars and we can rely on them to do their part.Gordon Morrison, chief executive ofthe Association of Scottish Visitor Attractions, has indicated that many outdoor attractions could reopen as soon as next weekend,Nicola Sturgeon confirms stage two of the Scottish Governmentrsquos roadmap to easing the lockdown later this week ndash but warned that ldquomany are weighing up whether it will be viable to open on July .He added: ldquoRegardless of when attractions choose to reopen, there will be a signicantly reduced number of visitors to our sites this year and there is absolutely no doubt that a longer-term support package for the sector will definitely be needed to ensure the survival of many of our members.Pubs and restaurants are eager to welcome customers again, with those with outdoor spaces set to be able to reopen in phase two of the exit strategy.Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the Scottish Beer  Pub Association, said: ldquoIt is important consumers feel safe and comfortable when they are finally allowed to enjoy a beer in a pub again, with operators across Scotland busy over the coming weeks getting their premises ready for opening in the new normal.ldquoThere are still issues needing addressed ahead of reopening for the pub sector though, with the majority of premises unable to viably operate at a two-metre social distance.

title: orkneys-stunning-heritage-star-new-film
story: Now, the ancient remains and Orkneyrsquos other intriguing monuments are to provide a magical backdrop to an animated feature film which could launch the story of the islands onto the international stage. Itrsquos hoped that Lugi ndash The Brodgar Boy could eventually become a major cinema release, helping to spotlight Orkney and, indeed, Scotlandrsquos often overlooked Neolithic history, echoing the impact of Pixarrsquos  animation Brave, and boosting tourism across the islands. The feature- film will tell the story of a disabled boy who must unite his peoplethey are to defeat evil forces, and is expected to take viewers on an animated tour of the Orkney Islandsrsquo most precious heritage sites. The idea originated from Orcadian illustrator and cartoonist Alex Leonard who has been developing the film with Belfast-based animation company ALT Animation. It recently beat competition from almost  filmmakers in  countries to secure major development funding from Creative Europe. ALT Animation has also received support from Northern Ireland Screen. Intended as a family-friendly movie, the story will use the boy herorsquos adventures to explore some of the mysteries surrounding Orkneyrsquos most ancient monuments, such as the famous settlement of Skara Brae and the Ring Of Brodgar. The sites predate Stonehenge and the Pyramids of Egypt, prompting suggestions that the islands were the epicentre of human existence , years ago. Although strictly fiction, it will be woven around real archaeological evidence and understanding gleaned during excavation of the sites. Some early illustrations have been based on Structure Ten at the Ness, thought to be one of the largest stone-built Neolithic structures in Britain and built around BC.Measuring ft by ft, archaeologists believe it was abandoned around BC, when hundreds of cattle were slaughtered and consumed during a huge feast. Leonard, who lives in Sandwick, was inspired to create the character and dramatic backdrop to the story after visiting the Ness of Brodgar settlement in  and being astounded by its size and history. ldquoI couldnrsquot really grasp fully the scale of what they are finding in terms of the number of buildings and the size of them. I was captivated and couldnrsquot understand why more people didnrsquot know about it, he said. ldquoI kept wondering what it looked like when Ness was in its prime. I went home and started to draw and sketch ideas. ldquoIt was a labour of love that at first I thought could make a little kidsrsquo book.The idea attracted the attention of Tim Bryans, writer and producer from Belfast-based ALT Animation, which has now secured interest from a number of award-winning studios around Europe keen to work collectively on the project.Leonard said the focus is now oncreating a screenplay and a trailer that showcases the story, and looking for a partner to take the film to full production. ldquoWe would love to think that it would eventually go on general release, added Leonard. ldquoWe donrsquot know who will come on board and donrsquot know yetit will be computer generation, D, an arthouse project or have much wider appeal. We are just happy for it to have found its feet.ldquoOur inspiration is Pixarrsquos Brave which did so well for tourism in Scotland.Brave, which told the story of an adventurous princess and featured the voice of Billy Connolly and Kelly Macdonald, was a global hit and resulted in tourism agency VisitScotland spending pound million on the joint marketing campaign with Disney. The associated television campaign was said to have reached around  million people in the UK, North America and Europe, while written material reached  million people worldwide.The film was estimated to have generated more than poundm in business for Scotland over  years.

title: sir-tom-devine-scotlands-role-slavery-must-acknowledged
story: Devine says that attacking statues of public figures connected to the th and th-century slave trade ldquoachieves little and fails to acknowledge the real truth of historic Scottish involvement in the slave systems.ldquoTargeting statues is a largely meaningless gesture which might make some people feel good about themselves for a little while, he says. ldquoThis though, does little to address the very real and ongoing issue of racial prejudice in Scotland and throughout the UK.Devine spoke out at the end of a week in which attention in Scotland has been focused on the imposing statue of Henry Dundas in Edinburghrsquos St Andrew Square which dominates the city centre.Dundas, one of the most powerful figures in Scotland in the early-th century, used his influence to delay the abolition of the Atlantic slave trade by  years. Edinburgh City Council is to consider a plan to rededicate the statue to those who continued to suffer enslavement during this period.Across the world other statues have been targeted in the wake of international protests about the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis two weeks ago. In Bristol last Sunday, a statue of the th-century slave trader, Edward Colston, was felled by protesters and flung into the harbour.Devine insisted that focusing merely on statues and other artefacts from the past was misplaced. ldquoIf people want to talk about Scottish involvement in slavery they need to be aware of the full picture. In the th and early-th centuries the Scottish nation as a whole was lsquocomplicitrsquo in slavery. The markets and financial s from lsquothe nefarious businessrsquo helped to lay the foundation for modern Scotland and shaped the economy from which we now benefit.In , Devine edited a collection of essays about Scotlandrsquos historic involvement in the slave plantations. Recovering Scotlandrsquos Slavery Past demonstrated how all levels of Scottish society, from the early-th century to the end of slavery in the British Empire, were directly or indirectly affected.:Without slavery Glasgow wouldnt exist: The brutal truth about Scotlands slaving pastldquoThe new research showed that merely concentrating on prominent mercantile figures fails to take account of the fact that Scottish society as a whole benefited from chattel slavery: weavers of lsquoslave clothrsquo for the West Indies fishermen who exported dried fish to feed the slaves workers in the mills who processed the raw cotton harvested by slave labour the crews of the vessels who sailed across the Atlantic and the officials, lawyers and clergymen who administered the slave colonies and the spiritual needs of their owners.ldquoOnly by acknowledging the full extent of this nationrsquos role in slavery can we begin to construct a meaningful programme of response today to that dark period of history.lsquorsquoI am convinced that the evidence we now have suggests Scottish modernisation was even more dependent on the slavery factor than England. This was not because of involvement in the slave trade itself. Ships from Scottish ports rarely took part in that horrible commerce in human beings after . Rather it was based on the overwhelming place of tobacco, sugar and then cotton in Scottish external trade. The remarkable boom in these commodities depended entirely on armies of black slave labourers.In , Glasgow University published a report, based on more than two years of research, that revealed it benefited directly from the slave trade in Africa and the Caribbean in the th and th centuries. Its audit put the figure at pound million in todayrsquos money. Following this the university launched a wide-ranging ldquoreparative justice programme to include the creation of a centre for the study of slavery and to establish ties with the University of the West Indies.The study also raised questions about how the wealth of Glasgow and other parts of Scotland was accumulated. Devine praised the universityrsquos research and openness. ldquoThe research confirms that manmore Scots gained from the colonial trades based on slave labour than the tobacco lords and sugar princes who are now attracting such virulent media and political condemnation, he said.:Hundreds turn out lsquoto protectrsquo Glasgow war memorialldquoTherefore, it follows that today there must be institutions and families with links to those times and who prospered from the profits of chattel slavery. But so far, in Scotland, only the University of Glasgow has admitted how it benefited and how it intends to proceed by way of some form of recompense to the people of the West Indies. Why are others silent ldquoOne positive consequence of the current furore has been the triggering of a deeper awareness of the inequalities that black people in Britain and the US continue to encounter to this day and which have undeniable connections to slavery. ldquoYet in order to begin to heal that wound in Scotland, a soundly-based and open knowledge of the nationrsquos central part in slave history is an essential precondition.

title: jatin-haria-assume-infected-racism---vaccine-available
story: The Parliamentrsquos official position now includes the statement ldquothat there is a responsibility on us all to identy and dismantle barriers of structural racism that exist in our society and institutions.It might not seem it, but itrsquos a huge milestone for Scotland.Until recentlythe general line was that Scotland was exceptional, and ldquoitrsquos not all bad here.Wersquore really all Jock Tamsonrsquos bairns, we donrsquot have a class system, we only played a bit part in the Empire, we were ardent abolitionists, ordinary Scots didnrsquot see a single shilling of the money earned from the backsof enslaved Africans, we awarded Nelson Mandela the freedom of the city, we welcome immigrants.Exceptional, exceptional, exceptional.One or two of these points are indeed true. But you can be the exception to the rule and, in some cases, racist at the same time. David Hume, one of the most eminent philosophers in the Scottish Enlightenment and close friend of Adam Smith, thought ldquothere never was any civilised nation of any other complexion than white. Burns could believe A Manrsquos a Man for Arsquo That and still make plans to go to work as a slave driver in Jamaica. And never forget that it was Scottish emigrants who set up the Ku Klux Klan.Closer to home, the Scottish Government can state that ldquoScotland has a wonderfully erse society and we are all, each and every one of us, equal citizens and stakeholders of Scotland.At the same time, a charge of racial hate crime is levied against someone on average every three hours, every single day,  days every year. It comes as no surprise then that a third of all black minority ethnic people in Scotland report having experienced discrimination in the past two years.BME people are twice as likely to live in poverty as their white counterparts and, not coincidentally, inequality and discrimination persist in the labour market.Research shows someone with a non-British sounding name has to send nine times more applications in order to receive an interview. Public bodies try to get around this using ldquoname blind application processes, yet the Scottish Governmentrsquos own workforce data shows ethnic disparities of Ben Nevis proportions.Even more worrying was the data showing that between  and ,  murders with a known or suspected racist element were recorded, with many having littleany media interest.All too often these were seen as ldquoone-off incidents rather than any broader reflection on Scottish society. Yet during this period, these  cases gave Scotland a higher per-capita rate of murder associated with racism than England or Wales.In the last Social Attitudes Survey to look at discrimination, % of people in Scotland felt that there was sometimes a good reason to be prejudiced against certain groups.Thatrsquos more than one in every five of us. Itrsquos no wonder that more and more people are acknowledging that the ldquono problem here attitude needs to change into a beliefldquothat racism is a societal evil that we must all stand united against.A milestone has been reached ndash Scotlandrsquos parliamentary representatives are now standing up against racism. Itrsquos a small step forward. But standing up doesnrsquot move us any further forward.A key barrier to progress is peoplersquos assumption that they, personally, could never behave or think in a racist way. The truth is that anyone can. To solve this, perhaps we need to treat the pandemic of racism like we are being asked to treat Covid-.Assume you are infected. You may be asymptotic, but as Amy Cooper showed in Central Park, the symptoms can surface at any time. Follow the science and listen to those who know more than you about it. Keep the R number at  ndash donrsquot let racism spread.Andyour le is absolutely the same as it was before you acknowledged the racism ldquooutbreak, then you are doing something wrong.Luckily, a vaccine is already available ndash changing attitudes and behaviours. You can make changes for yourself, and help those around you to change. Learn more about social, structural and institutional racism believe people who say theyrsquore experiencing it educate people who want to downplay it.Donrsquot stand still, act. Letrsquos make the new normal an anti-racist one.Jatin Haria is executive director, Coalition for Racial Equality and Rights

title: north-sea-gave-liquid-gold-45-years-ago
story: The National Front marched in London, IRA bombs exploded, the Yorkshire Ripper was on the loose and coal miners celebrated a % pay rise watched, no doubt, by the new leader of the Conservative Party, Margaret Thatcher.And in the North Sea, an economic revolution was about to bubble up from the depths of the choppy waters.The feverish race to extract precious liquid gold from British waters had been played out since the sixties, as exploration companies used increasingly sophisticated technology to pinpoint oilfields which science suggested had to be somewhere.Finally, in mid-July  ndash exactly  years ago this week ndash the first of what would become countless billions of barrels of oil was brought ashore.A trickle at first, before long it would become a torrent wave after wave of luscious, thick, liquid gold that put the nation on its way to a more affluent future, launched Aberdeen as Europersquos oil capital, and sparked endless debates over whose oil it really was.Now, however, while a glut of North Sea oil languishes on ocean-going tankers following a collapse in demand and plunging prices, and the sector braces itself for its endgame, the heady days of  feel like a world away.And it may beg the question of what might have happenedall that oil hadnrsquot been found Pioneering and rival exploration companies had spent years trawling the North Sea for oil when, in September , BPrsquos semi-submersible rig Sea Quest drilled into what would become the Arbroath field and, a year later, the Forties field.In an interview given four decades later to mark the Fortiesrsquo anniversary, former Sea Quest driller Rob Lingard would tell how he ran to the messroom, grabbed a Colmanrsquos horseradish sauce bottle and snatched the first glug of black liquid gold to emerge from its depths.ldquoWhen I think back to that little, tiny rig we had up there compared to the size of them now, we did well, he recalled.ldquoWe were drilling away and the rig man said lsquoersquove got some oil on the shakersrsquo. We knew wersquod got into oil but we didnrsquot quite realise how big it was.But while BP had pinpointed the UKrsquos largest oilfield ndash quickly followed by Shellrsquos Brent ndash it would be Denver-based Hamilton Brothers, working on Argyll, km southeast of Aberdeen, that would win the race to bring oil ashore.Using a floating, semi-submersible drilling rig, the Transworld , modied to operate as a production , oil was pumped onto the ,-ton tanker Theogennitor.Within a week, on June , , the then energy minister Tony Benn was on board a hydrofoil at Tower Pier in London, heading down river to BPrsquos Isle of Grain refinery in the Medway Estuary to greet the tanker and its valuable cargo.ldquoI hold the future of Britain in my hand, he declared, clutching a bottle of the tankerrsquos crude oil aloft, adding that Britain was set to be one of the worldrsquos  great oil-producing nations.Before long, BP would be bringing its own oil ashore.In November , the Queen pressed a gold button to mark the opening of a pipeline at Cruden Bay which could whisk up to , barrels of BP oil on a -mile journey to the refinery at Grangemouth.Soon the black river was in full flow. By , Forties fieldrsquos four pound million BP rigs had produced . million tons of oil andhelped ensure Britain was no longer at the mercy of Opec oil prices.Within a decade, . million barrels of oil per day were being extracted from  North Sea fields across more than  installations.As more companies raced to take out leases to extract oil, terminals were built in Orkney and Shetland. Sullom Voe alone brought work for  people while Aberdeen shted attention from fishing to became Europersquos Klondike.Family businesses built on cod and herring switched to oil. The most successful, run by Sir Ian Wood, would become a multinational oil services company helping him towards an estimated net worth today of . billion.Aberdeen, meanwhile, boomed and losses felt by drting tourism and cod wars were offset by rich oilmen with very deep pockets.All of which couldnrsquot have come at a better time, as traditional industries across the UK collapsed, coal mines and shipyards closed, and car production ground to a halt.By the mid-s, the North Sea was providing % of the Treasuryrsquos revenues, enabling Conservative government tax cuts, covering the costs of unemployment, and paying off a historic balance of payments problem.And it provided a cushion for Margaret Thatcher to carry out sweeping industrial reforms while funding a consumer boom when, some argue, the income should instead have been invested in a Norwegian-style oil fund.While the SNP continued to declare it was Scotlandrsquos oil, the North Sea was, according to Tony Blair in , ldquoutterly essential to Mrs Thatcherrsquos electoral success.Few working offshore would have complained too much. Their  days on, five days off routine brought extremely good pay: the average salary within the oil and gas sector in  was pound, a year.But there was also constant danger. In the early days, workers were transported in helicopters without wearing harnesses, puffing on fags as they went. If weather grounded flights, some would be ferried from boats to rigs, clinging on to ropes high above crashing waves.Concerns that safety was not a high priority seemed validated in  by the Piper Alpha disaster which claimed the lives of  men and prompted improved health and safety measures. Helicopter crashes also brought tragedy to the sector.But still the black gold flowed. By the early s, the Forties field alone had delivered over two billion barrels of oil, while oil gushed from the North Sea at the equivalent of . million barrels every day, supporting , jobs across the UK.No-one can really know what would have happenedwe hadnrsquot found oil on our doorstep whether we would have been forced to innovate and find new, cleaner methods of providing energy earlier, embraced windfarms and electric vehicles sooner, or limped into economic catastrophe.However, itrsquos clear that a sector that is worth around poundbn to the economy, which supports around , jobs across the UK ndash % of them in Scotland ndash and has paid poundbn in production tax since the s, is changing.Ross Dornan, OGUKrsquos market intelligence manager, said: ldquoThe opening of the UKrsquos first oil pipeline serving the iconic Forties field was a major milestone in our industryrsquos history and a testament to the importance of North Sea oil to the UK economy which remains the case today.ldquoThe industry has gone on to make a hugely positive impact across the UK ndash producing more than  billion barrels of oil and gas, contributing hundreds of billions of pounds to the UK economy and supporting hundreds of thousands of high value jobs.ldquoToday, although the industry is facing some of its most dficult challenges, there is still signicant potential to be realised from the UK Continental Shelf.ldquoOur focus is on driving the recovery of our industry so we can make the most of future opportunities including our contribution to delivering energy security and playing a key role in the transition to a low carbon economy.

title: shops-call-re-opening-date-announced
story: The Scottish Retail Consortium wants a provisional reopening date so shops can prepare to open their doors to customers again.Non-essential shops have been shut since lockdown began on March  and many are facing a battle to survive the longer their doors remain closed.In England, clothes stores and bookshops are starting to open again from tomorrow but there is no date yet when this might happen in Scotland.Ewan MacDonald-Russell of the Scottish Retail Consortium said: ldquoWe really need an indicative timetable so we can put the right measures in place so wersquore ready to trade and customers can have a bit of confidence when they can come back to shops and get the products wersquore all hoping theyrsquoll want to buy.The Scottish Government has produced a route map out of lockdown with dferent measures occurring at dferent stages but no dates are attached to the phases.A spokesman said: ldquoWe have a review point on Thursday at which time we will consider further, safe progression through the route map.ldquoOur total package for businesses during this unprecedented economic crisis now exceeds pound. billion. This support, which is under constant review, includes almost poundm of non-domestic rates relief and a pound.bn business grants scheme.ldquoImportantly, we have extended the eligibility criteria for our small business and retail, hospitality and leisure grants, and we have extended the upper threshold for retail, hospitality or leisure properties with inidual rateable values of up to pound, each. We have also published workplace guidance to support the retail sectorrsquosto trading.The national clinical director, Professor Jason Leitch, told BBC Scotland he was hopeful there could be good news for retailers soon. He said: ldquoShops will be part of our conversation this week as we move towards hopefully phase two of the route map on Thursday and Friday and conversations around next weekend.Retailers say they need a provisional date to help prepare shops for social distancing measures, bringing back staff and planning sales promotions.They also fear that the longer they are closed, the more people will shop on the internet, and perhaps continue to do so in the long term.Meanwhile, the Higher Education Minister has warned that Scottish universities could suffer long-term damage caused by the Covid- outbreak as well as losing access to European funds as Britain leaves the EU.The Scottish Funding Councilrsquos recent analysis suggests the countryrsquos universities will lose around poundm this year and between poundm and poundm next year Richad has written to the UK Science Minister Amanda Solloway: ldquoItrsquos vital both for Scotlandrsquos economic recovery and to protect the nationrsquos global reputation for science and research excellence that the UK Treasury signals substantial support for our universities in the coming days.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  One Glasgow boy ran to tell the farmer    39 they coos are eating a    your grass  39
story: With falling temperatures, the village moved back indoors. Yoursquod scarcely know that there has been any lting of lockdown. One neighbour says her grandmother scoffs at the idea that the coronavirus crisis is like the last war, when she was a child in a nearby town. Although they were often hungry, they had complete freedom. Even when the air raid siren went, and they had to e into shelters, they did not feel the all-pervasive threat of today.Nor, unless they were extremely remote or unlucky, were people shut off from each other. We talk a lot about the power of modern technology to keep us connected, but in those times, whether you were in a village or a city, there was daily contact with other folk, evenyou lived alone. People wouldnrsquot have felt the need for video calls when they could nip out of theirdoor and visit whoever they liked nearby. The Blitz spirit is not entirely a myth, but the circumstances in which it thrived were very dferent from this pandemic.My mother lived in London and, in , like countless city children, was evacuated to the country. She was luckier than many, being sent not to strangers but to an aunt, who lived in Herefordshire, near the Welsh border. There was no running water, light was by paraffin lamp, her uncle was an irascible war veteran, and her aunt would often retreat to bed for days, finding the extra responsibility rather too much. But for an -year-old, collecting eggs from under hens, sauntering up the lane for still-warm jugs of milk from the farm, and seeing a night-time sky lit by stars was a revelation. From then on, she counted the days until she could leave London forever.Not all evacuees felt the same way. Encountering beetles and bugs for the first time was hard enough, but herds of cows with a bull among them must have been pretty alarming. One boy, who had never previously left the Gallowgate, ran to tell the farmer that ldquothey coos are eating arsquo your grass. Another Glaswegian, taken into a Perthshire home, escaped onto the roof when they ran him a bath. He thought they were trying to drown him.Recalling that period, my mother spoke of country folksrsquo shock at the poverty of inner city children, who had come from slums. Those who organised the mass evacuation were appalled to discover that, when asked to provide each child with a change of clothing, a toothbrush and enough food for a dayrsquos journey, a lot of families were unable to do so. It was a sobering eye-opener. Rural hardship was re, but it did not compare to the scale of urban deprivation: barefoot youngsters with rickets, scurvy, ringworm, or so underfed they were the colour of lard.Itrsquos hard to imagine what it must have felt like to be dropped into a world of fields and trees and pitch black nights, when you were used to well-lit canyons of concrete and stone or to find yourself alone in a bed, when usually therersquod be siblings on all sides, keeping you warm, and your parents only a step away. Some children were so miserable, they had to be sent home. For others, like my mother, it sparked a lelong love of the countryside.Not that she idealised her auntrsquos way of le. Some aspects of it were, for a Londoner, like stepping back in time. Nor, in the s, was there any glamorising of country le. It was often equated with backward attitudes and ignorance. If anything, most villagers dreamed of escaping to the city, or at least the suburbs, and a clean, warm house with all mod-cons.Irsquove been reading Dirk Bogardersquos memoir, Great Meadow, in which he recalls his childhood in the Sussex Downs, from the age of six. Between  and , he spent weekends and long spells of holiday in what his affluent parents called a cottage, but photos show as a substantial house. Later he was packed off to Glasgow, which he loathed, but thatrsquos another story. In Great Meadow, he and his little sister were looked after by a nanny, while his actress mother swanned around in a kimono, and his father raced up and down to London where he was on The Timesrsquos picture desk. Bogarde often mentions the healthiness of the country, compared to London, where public transport was frowned on, because of the risk of germs. This was a legacy, perhaps, of the Spanish flu.Bogarde loved everything about the cottage, but the most noteworthy feature was the outside lavatory. Every Friday he had to dig a hole in the garden and, under cover of dusk, empty the privy bucket into it. His great fear was of tripping, because sanitation was basic. Theyrsquod have a weekly bath, filled by their nanny, but his parents preferred going to the nearest pub for their ablutions.Years ago I visited friends in rural Perthshire who had an outside toilet. I rather liked it: it was made of wood, and smelled of sawdust. Unlike the shed at the bottom of many cottage gardens, one wall was open, so the view was lovely, even in the snow. You didnrsquot have to crunch over snails in the dark to reach it ndash bedrooms came with chamberpots ndash and as a guest there was no fear of ever being asked to empty it. To watch him on screen, yoursquod never think Bogarde was the man to cope with such a noisome task. If for any reason it suddenly becomes a necessary chore in our cottage, Irsquoll be with the Gallowgate evacuees, heading straight back to the flushing loos of the Merchant City.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: brave-midges-summer---tourism-sector-needs-us
story: Maybe your minds eye is conjuring a picturesque lochside lodge or a glamping pod on the beach. The world may not currently be our oyster, yet Scotland hopefully soon will.News that the tourism sector could reopen for business ndash with a provisional date set for July  ndash has seen me gazing starry-eyed at holiday accommodation websites like a lovestruck teenage girl mooning over posters of Bros and A-has Morten Harket on her bedroom wall.After all these weeks in lockdown, venturing a handful of miles at most, the idea of soon being able to travel further afield is a prospect giddying and slightly terrying in equal measure.The notion of staying overnight in another set of four walls ndash be it booking a caravan at Wemyss Bay or a BB in Banchory ndash is so alien, it feels akin to being selected for a Mars mission.Over the past three months, le beyond my own little nook has often felt like an abstract concept. Cocooned in our sanitised bubbles, theres been moments I have viewed Jim Carreys character in The Truman Show as a kindred spirit.: Susan Swarbrick: When lockdown is over do I need to wear a bra Except in my instance the all-seeing eye of the camera facilitates endless rounds of Zoom calls and theres no hidden door you can step through to escape.Surprisingly, I havent gone completely stir-crazy. It has perhaps helped that Im a homebody at the best of times. While I wouldnt go as far as snooker player Ronnie OSullivan, who last week described lockdown as "the best three months" of his le, Ive not experienced prolonged cabin fever.Yet, ever since the announcement that the reopening of holiday infrastructure could be imminent, I suddenly have itchy feet. This coming Saturday I was due to head off for a week at a cottage near Stranraer, another lockdown landmark that has only served to stoke my wanderlust.Regular readers will recall some months ago that I lamented never having visited Dundee. My hankering to explore the city hasnt waned. Well, unless those who didnt take my musings in the good-natured way intended are waiting at the Tay Bridge with torches and pitchforks.I feel strongly about the need to get out and support Scottish tourism as soon as is safe to do so. I usually avoid July and August when the midges are at their most ferocious, but this year Ill grin and bear it, armed with a vat of Avon Skin So Soft and a stack of antihistamines.: Susan Swarbrick: Ive been to Georgia and Calornia. But Ive never been to Dundee ...Ditto when it comes to any grumblings about the weather. Invest in a decent set of waterproofs. Put on a jumper and warm socks. Place your trust in the restorative powers of a hearty bowl of Cullen skink. Now, go stick a pin in the map. Ill look forward to giving you a wave on the open roads.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter   Bagpuss Boris  followed the wrong science
story: The PM is losing supporters left and right. The Government is rudderless, drting making contradictory decisions or no decisions at all.Boris Johnson had nothing sensible to say about the Black Lives Matter demos which drove a coach and horses through the lockdown. He could either have endorsed the protests as legitimate on moral grounds, or called on the police to enforce the law. He did neither until forced to. Leadership was lacking.The belated introduction of a -day quarantine for travellers to Britain seems like a self-destructive exercise in closing the door after the viral horse has bolted. His Government is cancelling border checks on the , lorries that enter the UK every day, while also saying that the Brexit transition period will not be extended.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson putting political interests ahead of the public interestJohnson is accused of allowing children in England to go to theme parks but not to schools, leading to further problems for students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The two-metre rule is causing massive problems as the economy tanks, yet the medical evidence for its effectiveness is contradictory.But the most serious accusation made last week against Boris Johnson was that he was asleep at the wheel in early March, and that his dilatory behaviour led to the deaths of tens of thousands of people.The claim was made by the former SAGE member, Professor Neil Ferguson .ldquoHad we introduced lockdown a week earlier, the Imperial College epidemiologist told MPs last week, ldquowersquod have reduced the final death toll by at least half.In other words,the UK Government had closed the schools and shops on March  instead of March , the official death toll might have been , instead of ,. This retrospectively validates Fergusonrsquos own forecast back in March that, on his model, lockdown should have kept the death toll to around ,.I think most now accept that the UK did just about everything wrong in its response to Covid-. We didnrsquot close the borders, didnrsquot protect care homes, abandoned testing and locked down too late.
